Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Evolution of Biodiversity across the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the Field Museum of Natural History, located in Chicago, IL, will support the training of 8 students for 10 weeks, during the summers of 2016-2018. Students will conduct hands-on research in biodiversity science and receive training in cutting-edge techniques and analysis in evolutionary biology through guided mentorship by museum curators and scientists. Students will learn research techniques that include DNA sequencing and computational analysis of genetic and genomic data, morphological measurements and phylogenetic analysis, and microbiology and next-generation microbial sequencing. Scientific projects to be conducted by the students include the evolution of morphological variation in extinct therapsids, tropical bird biogeography, population genetics of sharks, influence of disease on bird genetic diversity in urban environments, quantitative analysis of meteorites, the influence of hydrostatic pressure on morphological diversity in octopuses, and co-diversification of ants and their gut bacterial communities. In addition students will receive career mentoring in a diversity of STEM fields, gain experiences in public outreach and science communication, receive training in ethics/responsible conduct of research, and participate in a diversity workshop to help overcome bias in science. Selection of applicants will be completed by the host curator or scientist and students will be recruited from across the country, leveraging local university connections, to insure participation of underrepresented minorities. Students may apply online through: https://www.fieldmuseum.org/REU.

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted and will create a video about their research experience to share in an annual symposium. Students will gain experiences in public outreach and science communication through sharing their research on the public museum areas. In addition, many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. These internships will provide training for the next generation of evolutionary biologists in collections-based organismal bioscience.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://www.fieldmuseum.org/REU, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Corrie Moreau at cmoreau@fieldmuseum.org) or the co-PI (Dr. Thorsten Lumbsch at tlumbsch@fieldmuseum.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Between 2016 and 2018, the Field Museum’s REU program provided immersive, hands-on training in collections-based biodiversity science and evolutionary biology for 24 interns. Of these, fourteen have gone on to graduate school in the sciences, including PhD programs at Yale, University of Utah, and Berkeley.

Training the next-generation of STEM researchers is critical to address issues related to the loss and maintenance of biodiversity. With many universities no longer offering organismal-based biology classes and most of the population growing up in dense cities, many students never have the opportunity to experience biological diversity and the diverse ways scientists study it. By providing interns with hands-on experience conducting collection-based research in biodiversity, our program leverages the unique resources of one of the world's major natural history museums to bridge gaps in contemporary biological curricula and train future scientists in skills needed to resolve the current biodiversity crisis.

From 2016-2018, Field Museum REU interns conducted hands-on research in biodiversity science through close collaboration with a mentor, drawing on the distinctive opportunities for specimen-based research afforded by one of the world’s foremost natural-history collections. These specially-designed research projects exposed interns to the full range of biodiversity research carried out at the museum, including taxonomy, systematics, phylogenetics, phylogeography, biogeography, evolutionary biology, molecular biology, genomics, host-associated microbiomes, paleontology, and conservation biology. Interns received training in cutting-edge techniques and analysis in evolutionary biology, including morphological and next-generation genomic analysis, phylogenetic inference, and computational biology. In 2017 and 2018, we added an optional computational biology workshop run by the Museum’s genome analyst, which was open to all interested Museum interns; the majority of our REU interns participated. Museum REU interns also received career mentoring in a diversity of STEM fields and developed professional skills including abstract writing, CV preparation, and scientific poster design. Our program drew on the Museum’s public-education resources to provide interns with experiences in public outreach and science communication. Interns presented their projects to the public as part of the Museum’s “Meet a Scientist” program, and honed their science-communication skills through tours and presentations to other high school and undergraduate interns at the Museum as well as students and researchers at several area scientific institutions including the Chicago Botanic Garden and Morton Arboretum. Finally, Museum REU interns participated in a diversity workshop to help overcome bias in science. 

FMNH REU interns have made lasting contributions to the scientific community through their research. REU interns have presented their work at scientific meetings and coauthored publications with their mentors, as well as contributed to scientific infrastructure through their work. For example, DNA sequence data were generated by several interns in the program each year, and these sequences were accessioned into GenBank (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/). Interns have also generated algorithms used for extracting phylogenetic data from published trees as part of the Open Tree of Life project (www.opentreeoflife.org), prepared and measured specimens for research and accessioning into the FMNH collection, and produced resources such as SEM images and thin sections of fossil bones that will have continued value for their scientific peers. Finally, all Museum REU interns participated in a workshop in which they created and presented short videos aimed at a general audience about their research projects, which have been uploaded to the Museum’s Vimeo channel (https://vimeo.com/fieldmuseum.)
